WILLIAM MURRAY (police-constable L 84.) On the 21st of Septem
ber, at half-past five o'clock in the morning, I saw the two prisoners coming out of the gardens of the houses in Newport-street, Lambeth— Brown got over a wall, and made his escape—I followed Lewis over three or four gardens, till I got to the back of Mr. Gurney's brewhouse—I stopped there while an officer went and took him in a water-closet—a basket of lead pipes and cocks was found in the garden under the wall which I had seen both the prisoners on—these two cocks, which the pro
secutors claims, were in the basket.
WILIIAM DAVEY (police-constable L 169.) I took Lewis, but found nothing on him.
Brown's Defence. I know nothing of it at all.

BROWN—
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

LEWIS—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—(See the next case.)

2787.
THOMAS LEWIS was again indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of September, 1 sheet, value 6s.; 2 towels, value 1s.; and 1 blanket, value 2s.; the goods of
Henry Jaggs.

HARRIETT LONG . I live with my brother, Henry Jaggs, at Lambeth. On the 20th of September we had a sheet, and these other articles, safe in the wash-house, and the next morning they were missing—this now pro
duced is the sheet—it is my brother's.
WILLIAM MURRAY . On the 21st of October, at half-past five o'clock in the morning, I traced the prisoner across the walls, and saw him drop this sheet—my sergeant picked it up.

GUILTY .* Aged 19—
Transported for Seven Years.

2788.
MARY DOWLEY and
JOSEPH GROUT were indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of September, 1 gown, value 3s., the goods of
William Amor; and that Grout had been before convicted of felony.

ALFRED ROLFE RANDALL . I am servant to Mr. William Amor, of Lambeth-walk. On the morning of the 24th of September he had a gown hanging at the door for sale—I missed it when the policeman came in the evening—this now produced is it.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police constable L 31.) On the 24th of Sep
tember, between six and seven o'clock, I saw the two prisoners in com
pany near Newington church—I followed them to Lambeth-walk—I saw them go into the lobby of the prosecutor's shop—they came out and went about two hundred yards, then came back and went in again—I waited, and Dowley came out towards me—I stopped her, and took this gown worn under her shawl—Grout went across the road.
Dowley. I was coming down the walk, and saw the gown lying between the shop and the passage; I put it under my arm, and the policeman caught me; I said, "Let me go," and I gave him the gown.
ALFRED ROLFE RANDALL . No; the gown was tied up inside.

JAMES BROOK . I was with Goff—we watched the prisoners from Newington church—they were together all the time—I saw Dowley reach up and unpin the gown, and Grout was watching through the window at the time.
SAMUEL WRIGHT (police-constable P 172.) I produce a certificate of Grout's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—(read)—he is the person.

GROUT—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years.

DOWLEY—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

2789.
DAVID LUDLOW was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of October, 2 spades, value 2s., the goods of
Joseph Christian Hurst; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

SAMUEL HENRY HURST . I live with my father, Joseph Christian Hurst, at Camberwell. On the 1st of October I had two spades, which I put into the shed—I missed them on Monday, the 3rd—these produced are them.

JAMES GAZE . On Sunday, the 2nd of October, I slept in a cart with the prisoner, and between one and two o'clock in the morning he wanted me to go over into a garden with him—I would not, and he struck me in the mouth—he then went, and in a few minutes he brought back these spades, and put them under some dung by the side of the cart—the next morning I pawned them for 1s. each—I gave him the money—he bought some bread, and gave me part of it.
THOMAS PRITCHARD (police-constable P 167.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from the office of the Clerk of the Peace of Surrey—(read)—he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Transported for Seven Years—Convict Ship.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

2790.
CHARLES TAYLOR was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of October, 2 coats, value 14s. 2 pairs of boots, value 4s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 1s. 6d.; 1 pair of braces, value 6d.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 5s.; and 1 half-crown; the property of
Thomas Leadham; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

THOMAS LEADHAM . I live in William-street, New Cut, Lambeth. I had the two coats and other articles safe in my bed-room on the 15th of Octo
ber—I missed them on the 16th, when I awoke in the morning—I knew the prisoner by his coming to my shop in the beginning of October—he stated he was in want of a lodging, and I took him in to lodge—he left me at the time I missed the property—I found "him in Westminster, with the coat, braces, and boots on him.
JOHN CONSTABLE (police-constable L 43.) I received the prisoner from the prosecutor—he had these things on him.

Prisoner. The coat and braces and the handkerchief were my own arti
cles; in the first instance I exchanged with the prosecutor for the hand-kerchief he had on, and then the braces, and then my coat, being out of work; I was in great distress.

THOMAS LEADHAM
re-examined. He did change with me, but he did not leave his things—he took his own, and mine too—I believe he was in distress.
WILLIAM POOLE (police-constable M 33.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from the office of the Clerk of the teace of Surrey—(read)—he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Year.

2792.
RICHARD CANTLIN was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of September, 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Henry Remington, from his person; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

HENRY REMINGTON . I am a merchant, and live in St. Thomas the Apostle. On the 24th of September, about eight o'clock in the evening, I was going down Newington-causeway—I felt something at my pocket, and missed my handkerchief—I turned sharply round, and saw the pri
soner close at my back—he passed by me—I went and caught him, and said, "You have taken my handkerchief—he pulled my handkerchief out of his pocket, and gave it me—this is it.
Prisoner. I kicked against something, and picked up this handkerchief. Witness. It is not possible—I felt him at my pocket distinctly, which made me turn round.
JAMES TIDMAKSH (police-constable M 51.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from the office of the Clerk of the Peace of Surrey—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2792.
ELIZABETH ALLBRIGHT was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of September, 1 blanket, value 1s. 6d.; 2 sheets, value 2s.; 2 irons, value 1s. 6d.; 3 plates, value 6d.; 2 tea cups, value 3d.; 2 saucers, value 3d.; 2 knives, value 6d.; 2 forks, value 6d.; 1 gown, value 2s.; 1 hammer, value 6d.; and 12 staircase rails, value 2s.; the goods of
Sarah Dean: and that she had been before convicted of felony.

SARAH DEAN . I live in Lambeth-walk. The prisoner engaged a fur
nished room in my house, at 1s. 6d. a week, in the middle of August—on the 29th of September, she had not been home all night, and I missed first two irons, and then the rest of the articles stated in the indictment—some of them had been in her room—and all of them were in my possession when she came to lodge with me.

Prisoner. I had no key to the room—it was open to the street—she gave me warning to leave, but my time was not up till the Tuesday—I left the gown and blanket in the room—another person occupied the room—the stair-rails were under the bed—I never took any thing. Wit-ness. The other person had left the room more than a week—the stair
rails were put under the bed to make a little alteration—there were two dozen of them, and when she was gone there was only one dozen left—there was a key to the room door—she could have locked it.
ALFRED ROLFE RANDALL . I am in the service of Mr. Amor, a pawn-broker. I have two sheets, pawned in the name of Mary Jones, one on the 31st of August, and the other on the 4th of September.

TIMOTHY BROSMAN (police-constable L 124.) I received charge of the prisoner from Mrs. Dean—she gave me a duplicate of one sheet pawned at Mr. Faulkner's—she was then searched in my presence, and the duplicates of the two sheets pawned at Mr. Amor's were found on her—Mrs. Dean had followed her to a new lodging which she had taken, but the prisoner had not slept there—I found this flat-iron there, and the prisoner told me it belonged to Mrs. Dean, and that she had taken the two sheets from Mrs. Dean's, and pawned them with an intention of releasing them as soon as she had received some money.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I had nothing to do, and certainly did pledge the sheets to get a bit of food; I have been turned from my home for seven years by my husband, who has married another woman; I have had but 1l. 2s. 6d. from him since.

THOMAS TUNSTALL (police-constable B 90.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at the office of the Clerk of the Peace of Westminster—(read)—the prisoner is the woman.

GUILTY . Aged 53.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2793.
WILLIAM SKEYOFF was indicted
for unlawfully breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Jones, at Lambeth, on the 5th of October, with intent to steal.—2nd COUNT, for entering the said dwelling-house with like intent.

ANN DELL . I am servant to Mr. John Jones, who lives at Herne-hill. On the 5th of October I heard a noise in the pantry, about half-past two o'clock—I went and saw the prisoner standing with his back towards me in the pantry, close by the window, which was a little way open—the window comes down very near to the ground—he got out on his knees—I pushed the window up, and jumped out after him and followed him—there was a screw broken in the window.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Is your master here? A. No—his daughter lives in the same house, and four servants—nothing was taken from the house—the prisoner had combs in his pocket for sale—I have heard my master say the house is in the parish of Lambeth.

WILLIAM JESSE (police-constable P 135.) I took the prisoner in an en
closed shrubbery, at Mr. Simpson's, which is eight hundred yards from Mr. Jones's—he had no business there—he got over a six-feet fence—I exam
ined the pantry-window—it had been forced open, and the screw was broken—the house is in the parish of St. Mary, Lambeth.
Cross-examined. Q. Is there any such parish as Lambeth? A. Till I got to the office I did not know it was called St. Mary, Lambeth—I always heard it called Lambeth.
WILLIAM HEMP . The house is in the parish of St. Mary, Lambeth—I have a house of my own there.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

2794.
WILLIAM TATHAM was indicted
for the wilful murder of
Edward Hills, on the high seas, within the jurisdiction of the Admiralty.

WILLIAM JONES . I was steward of the Dido, which was at sea in Janu
ary last, lying in Benin-roads, about fifteen miles from land, on the west coast of Africa—Philip Carpenter was the master—the prisoner was chief mate—Edward Hills was second mate—on the 12th of January Mr. Carpen
ter went up the Benin river, leaving the prisoner in command of the ship— Hills was also left—in the evening the prisoner and Hills were both very much in liquor, and were quarrelling in the cabin—they appeared to be reconciled, and very good friends before they went to bed—on the morning of the 13th I was in the cabin, making the breakfast—the prisoner, Mr. Morgans, the surgeon, and Hills, the second-mate, were there—Hills came down after all the others—as he was coming down, the prisoner asked if I had called him—I said, "Yes"—he said, "What is keeping the d—d old fool from his breakfast?"—Hills was coming down the ladder at the time, and heard it—he came down the ladder into the cabin—the prisoner said, "Here comes that d—d old fool to his breakfast"—Hills repeated the words to himself, "Here comes that d—d old fool"—they had some words between them, which I did not pay much attention to, but after awhile I heard the prisoner say Hills kept private societies forward among the men—Hills stood up, shook his hand across the table at him, and said, "By G—d, Mr. Tatham, if you were on deck you would not tell me so," put
ting his fist near him—it did not go within eighteen inches of his face,

as the table was between them—he could have struck him—on that, Tatham said, "No, but I could do this," and standing up, caught hold of the carving-knife, laid over the table, and plunged it into Hills' breast—Hills made one exclamation, and fell back, dead on the ladder—he said, "O my G—d, I am dead"—he expired in less than two minutes—I ran on deck, sung out "Murder," and Tatham was put in irons—before he was put in irons, when we got Hills on deck, he came up, and asked if he was dead—we said, "Yes"—as soon as he saw he was dead, he ran down into the cabin, caught hold of the knife, and commenced stabbing himself—he gave himself two severe stabs—I caught hold of him, brought him on deck, and put him in irons.

GUILTY of Manslaughter. Aged 33.—
Transported for Life.
ADJOURNED TO THE 29TH DAY OF NOV.

p.hi: The prisoners whose judgment was respited at the time of trial, have been sentenced as follows:

div0.p: Frederick Kalmus... 116.. Transported for Fifteen Years.
Charles Young... 269.. Transported for Fifteen Years.
Thomas Frogg... 520.. Transported for Seven Years.
Violet Drysdale... 653.. Transported for Seven Years.—Penitentiary.
William Smith Henson... 875.. Confined One Year.
David Henry Gilchrist... 965.. Transported for Seven Years.
John Odell Rathbone... 963.. Transported for Seven Years.
William Tyler, Printer, Bolt Court, London.
